contents.context:
South Korea is cracking down on hit-and-run offenders and DUI collisions.
Starting next month, hit-and-run drivers and those responsible for drunk driving collisions resulting in death will be legally liable for up to 154 million won in damages, or about 125 thousand U.S. dollars, even if they have insurance.
That's under a revision to the country's standardized car insurance agreement.
Up until now the liability for the responsible person was 4 million won, or about 32-hundred dollars.
Reporter : jy_rachel@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Personal liability for deadly car crashes raised to US$ 125,000
Updated: 2020-05-27 17:07:51 KST

contents.context:
South Korea's GDP ranked tenth among 38 advanced and emerging economies in 2019, down two notches from the previous year.
That's according to the OECD, which says Asia's fourth-largest economy totaled one.six trillion U.S. dollars in nominal GDP last year marking the country's first drop in the global GDP ranking since the 2008 global financial crisis.
As for the nominal economic growth last year, South Korea's stood at 1.4 percent the third-lowest among 47 countries surveyed by the Paris-based organization.
Meanwhile, a survey of industry groups around the world has found that more than half expect the impact of the COVID-19 on the global economy to last longer than a year.
The OECD surveyed businesses in 20 member states which together account for 73 percent of the world's GDP.
Reporter : jhee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea's GDP ranked 10th worldwide in 2019, down two notches: OECD
Updated: 2020-05-27 17:02:15 KST

contents.context:
Time now for an in-depth look at the market news this afternoon.
And for that, I'm joined on the line by Dr. Yang Jun-sok, professor of economics at the Catholic University of Korea.
Professor Yang, thank you for coming on today.

Thank you.

Wall Street opened back up on Tuesday, and like other markets, all three indexes were strongly higher on anticipation for a coronavirus vaccine. Korean stocks up and down today. What's the story in the global markets and Korea?

It seems like sentiment is recovering in businesses hit by the outbreak. But thinks are still rough for manufacturers that depend on exports. How's the economy doing, and what's your outlook in terms of a recovery?

Last year, according to the OECD, Korea's ranking in terms of nominal GDP fell two spots to 10th in the world. That was the first time it's fallen since 2008, using the OECD data. Tell us about that.

Alright, Professor Yang.
We'll have to leave it there for now.
Thanks so much for making time today.
Reporter : devin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
In-depth: Global market wrap-up
Updated: 2020-05-27 13:20:46 KST

contents.context:
In March, South Korea reported more deaths than births for a fifth consecutive month.
Data from Statistics Korea on Wednesday, showed there were a little over 24-thousand births in March, down more than 10 percent on-year.
The number of births has been declining for 52 straight months.
The country recorded almost 26-thousand deaths in March, an on-year increase of 3.6 percent.
Marriages were down one percent on-year, while the number of divorces plummeted by almost 20 percent.
Reporter : jhee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
No. of births in S. Korea down 10.1% y/y in March; deaths up 3.6% y/y
Updated: 2020-05-27 13:18:10 KST

contents.context:
Of 38 major and developing economies around the world-- South Korea's rank in terms of gross domestic product fell two slots to tenth last year.
According to an OECD report Wednesday, the GDP of Asia's fourth largest economy in 2019 was one.six trillion U.S. dollars, down from eighth the previous year.
This is the first time in eleven years that the country's GDP ranking has fallen.
The OECD added that the drop comes as South Korea's nominal economic growth rate came in at one.four percent last year.
Reporter : ashin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
S. Korea's GDP ranked 10th worldwide in 2019, down 2 notches from 2018: OECD
Updated: 2020-05-27 09:52:33 KST

contents.context:
South Korea's business sentiment for May edged up across all industries, but was still in the doldrums.
The Bank of Korea says the index for all industries was up two points on-month to 53.
The index was up six points for non-manufacturers.
But it was down three points for manufacturers who pointed to economic uncertainties, sluggish domestic demand as well as poor exports during the COVID-19 pandemic.
The same goes for the business outlook for June it rose six points for non-manufacturers but fell slightly for manufacturers.
The economic sentiment index, which includes consumer sentiment, rose over two points to at almost 58.
Reporter : damikim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea's business sentiment for May slightly up on-month to 53: BOK
Updated: 2020-05-27 09:52:33 KST

contents.context:
Samsung Electronics Vice Chairman Lee Jae-yong returned home early Wednesday after a 17 hour-long grilling by prosecutors in relation to the 2015 merger of two Samsung affiliates.
Lee appeared before prosecutors at 8AM Tuesday, and returned home at around 1:30AM this morning.
Prosecutors may summon him again, if necessary,
His summons is in regards to the merger of Samsung C&T and Cheil Industries in 2015, which has long been under scrutiny.
There are suspicions that management may have intentionally lowered the value of Samsung C&T to help Lee secure control of the company, as he was Cheil Industries' largest shareholder.
Lee reportedly denied any involvement during the questioning.
Reporter : yoonjm@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Samsung heir Lee Jae-yong questioned over 2015 merger
Updated: 2020-05-27 07:00:51 KST

contents.context:
Now to the numbers on the market,
Wall Street ended on the defense Tuesday with news the Trump administration is considering a range of sanctions on Chinese officials, businesses and financial institutions.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average picked up 2-percent to close just shy of 25-thousand.
The S&P 500 rallied one.2 percent to 29-91 while the NASDAQ lagged a bit, edging up just point-2 percent at the close.
Oil prices were on the rise with Brent Crude adding one.8 percent.
WTI was up nearly 3-percent to close at 34-dollars 22-cents a barrel.
Reporter : ashin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
Market wrap-up
Updated: 2020-05-27 06:00:58 KST

contents.context:
Prosecutors summoned Samsung Electronics Vice Chairman Lee Jae-yong , for questioning in relation to the 2015 merger of two Samsung affiliates.
Lee appeared before prosecutors from 8 AM Tuesday, as the merger of Samsung C&T and Cheil Industries was put under scrutiny.
There were suspicions that management may have intentionally lowered the value of Samsung C&T to help Lee secure control of the company, as he was the largest shareholder of Cheil Industries.
There are also allegations surrounding an what was perceived as an intentional inflation in the value of Cheil Industries ahead of the merger.
Samsung earlier said that it has never deliberately manipulated the value of any of its affiliates.
Reporter : mokyeon90@gmail.com
contents.headline:
Prosecutors summon Samsung heir over 2015 merger of two affiliates
Updated: 2020-05-26 17:06:17 KST

contents.context:
Traditional markets around South Korea have been bustling with customers recently as more people are going to these markets to spend their COVID-19 emergency relief funds.
The funds are frequently used at local markets, mom-and-pop stores, and convenience stores, helping boost consumption, which had been dampened by the pandemic.

"Our customers use the relief funds a lot. Some buy peanuts and other products twice as often as usual. The relief funds are helping our sales and activating customers."

"With the majority of people in South Korea having received the relief funds, local markets and stores say they have seen sales start to pick up thanks to the aid."

Local supermarkets are also seeing an increase in customers, as more people have started opening their wallets to spend the relief funds.

"It is effective. Our shop has seen sales increase by 20 percent. Customers use the funds a lot and they often ask if they can use the relief funds here."

More than nine out of 10 households in South Korea have received COVID-19 emergency relief funds over the past three weeks.
The safety ministry said Tuesday that almost 11-billion U.S. dollars of funds, or some 91 percent of the total amount had been handed out by May 25th.
So far, nearly 95 percent of the total households eligible for funds have received the aid.
Most households received the funds in the form of card points, while others got cash or vouchers.
With the government's relief funds circulating in the market, the country expects consumer sentiment to gradually pick up again after the impact of the pandemic.
Yoon Jung-min, Arirang News.
Reporter : yoonjm@arirang.com
contents.headline:
COVID-19 relief funds help restart spending in S. Korea
Updated: 2020-05-26 17:05:39 KST

contents.context:
The COVID-19 pandemic has forced some of South Korea's major conglomerates to change their recruitment methods during the first half of the year.

"For the first time ever, South Korea's largest conglomerate, Samsung Group, will be holding its Global Samsung Aptitude Test online."

Tens of thousands of job applicants will sit the Aptitude Test, called GSAT, for the first half of this year, at home, under remote monitoring.
Samsung held an online orientation on Tuesday, to check the connection and testing system. The tests will be held over two days, on May 30th and May 31st, to prevent any internet connection problems.
Samsung has also sent out a package containing a smartphone holder, so that applicants can be monitored while they take the test, and an ID card cover, to ensure that certain personal information isn't visible.
SK Group, held their aptitude test for new employees last Sunday.
The 'SK Competency Test' was carried out offline, but under strict quarantine measures.
Job applicants had their temperatures checked, and were required to wear face masks and gloves.
But SK C&C says it will hold their tests online, on June 6th.
Meanwhile, Lotte's hiring test called the L-TAB will be taken both online and offline.
The Group's compatibility test will be taken online while the assessment of one's ability to carry out tasks will be conducted offline.
Posco also held its entrance exam in mid-May, while complying with social distancing measures.
Meanwhile, KT has ended conventional mass recruitment and shifted to hiring on-demand in March, following Hyundai Motor Group which made the same transition early last year.
Only half of South Korea's top 10 conglomerates have carried out mass recruitment drives for the first half of this year due to the pandemic.
Kim Jae-hee, Arirang News.
Reporter : jhee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
COVID-19 outbreak changes hiring process of South Korean conglomerates
Updated: 2020-05-26 17:05:34 KST

contents.context:
To help the local travel industry recover from the COVID-19 outbreak,the South Korean government is rolling out measures to increase demand for local tours.
Tourism Minister Park Yang-woo announced the measures following a government meeting on Tuesday.
They include giving out up to one million discount coupons for accommodation and extending the travel promotion period.
That period will now run for one month from June 20th, during which transport costs will be significantly cut.
Discounts of up to 60 percent will be offered at amusement parks nationwide and up to 150-thousand people will be able to purchase tour packages with a 30 percent discount.
Reporter : jy_rachel@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korean government rolls out measures to promote local tours
Updated: 2020-05-26 17:04:48 KST
